projects.title: Interactionism for the discerning mind?
projects.description:
Forthcoming in [Philosophical Studies](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11098-018-1213-5)

I argue that interactionists have trouble making sense of how minds could influence the right neurons in a brain to produce the range of behaviors of which we are capable.

projects.title: The Unity of Moral Attitudes
projects.description:
Final version: Canadian Philosophy Review 2018

This paper offers my solution to the problem explored in my  'The Problem of Other Attitudes'. According to this solution, moral attitudes are distinguished by their functional properties in a restricted range of contexts, and by the the resemblance of their ingredients in other contexts.

projects.title: In Defense of Artificial Replacement
projects.description:
Final version: [Bioethics 2017](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/bioe.12340)

If it is within our power to provide a significantly better world for future generations at a comparatively small cost to ourselves, we have a strong moral reason to do so. One way of providing a significantly better world may involve replacing our species with something better. It is plausible that in the not-too-distant future, we will be able to create artificially intelligent creatures with whatever physical and psychological traits we choose. Granted this assumption, it is argued that we should engineer our extinction so that our planet's resources can be devoted to making artificial creatures with better lives.

projects.title: Hidden Qualia
projects.description:
Final version: [Review of Philosophy and Psychology 2017](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s13164-015-0297-5)

In this paper, I propose that those who reject higher-order theories of consciousness should not rule out the possibility of having conscious experiences that they cannot introspect.

projects.title: The Problem of Other Attitudes
projects.description:
Final version: American Philosophical Quarterly 2017

This paper presents a related problem concerning how noncognitivists might extend their accounts of moral judgments to other kinds of moral attitudes, such as moral hopes and moral intuitions. After presenting the problem, several contemporary theories with some initial promise for solving it are examined and found to be insufficient.

projects.title: A Primitive Solution to the Negation Problem
projects.description:
Final version: [Ethical Theory and Moral Practice 2016](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10677-015-9670-9)

A response to Unwin and Schroeder's Negation Problem. I make the case that metaethical expressivists should be unbothered by a large number of brute norms, and hence that they should be free to postulate their way out of the negation problem.
